Only a few trading days left..

There are 8 trading days left this year. The year has already been very sanguine and given the lack of volatility previously and the generally positive forward looking environment I find a very low likelihood that the S&P 500 will fall by 20% or more over the next 8 days. Also, many portfolio managers will not make any bold moves given that its the end of the year. The only item to push the market lower is a 'black swan' event. I give it a 1% probability of happening over the next 8 days. That is why I am projecting that its a 1% 'Yes' that the market will fall 20% or more.
Very little time left. Only possibility left is 1987 scenario.

Tax-loss selling to pressure 2017's losers in December NEW YORK (Reuters) - Stocks that have been lackluster so far in 2017 are unlikely to see their fortunes reversed in the final month of the year, as investors engage in tax-harvesting practices before the new year. Investors often exercise tax-loss selling strategies, dumping stocks that have performed poorly in order to reduce or eliminate capital gains taxes, as the year draws to a close.
“This is something we do every December, we take losses for clients who we’ve created gains for,” said Jake Dollarhide, chief executive officer of Longbow Asset Management in Tulsa, Oklahoma. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-stocks-weekahead/tax-loss-selling-to-pressure-2017s-losers-in-december-idUSKBN1E22AZ Average return over last 2 years has been negative in December. 1 up years; 1 down years;  ave. return = -0.07%

Goldman Sachs implies, but doesn't explicity state, how the 1920s ended with the Great Depression. 1.Goldman Warns That Stocks Are at Their Highest Valuations Since 1900 A prolonged bull market across stocks, bonds and credit has left a measure of average valuation at the highest since 1900, a condition that at some point is going to translate into pain for investors, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. “It has seldom been the case that equities, bonds and credit have been similarly expensive at the same time, only in the Roaring ’20s and the Golden ’50s,” Goldman Sachs International strategists including Christian Mueller-Glissman wrote in a note this week. “All good things must come to an end” and “there will be a bear market, eventually” they said.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-29/goldman-warns-highest-valuations-since-1900-mean-pain-is-coming 2. In fact, the S&P 500 hasn't fallen 3% from a previous high point (over one day or several days) since the slump that ended on November 4, 2016, four days prior to the election.That 388-day stretch is the longest the S&P 500 has ever gone without a 3% or more retreat, according to Bespoke Investment Group. (It's 18 days longer than the previous record, which was set in 1995.) 
http://money.cnn.com/2017/11/26/investing/stocks-week-ahead-sp-500/ 3.What is the 'Mean Reversion' Mean reversion is the theory suggesting that prices and returns eventually move back toward the mean or average. 
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/meanreversion.asp 4.Todd Gordon, founder of TradingAnalysis.com, says that the "Elliott wave" theory shows that while the S&P 500 has more room to rally, it will ultimately fall once it reaches a certain level. The framework, invented by Ralph Nelson Elliott, posits that each bull market rally goes through five different "waves" before a pullback occurs, with the first, third, and fifth waves moving upward while pullbacks happen in the second and fourth waves. According to Gordon, the market is currently in that fifth and final upward wave. While the S&P 500 continues to climb, as it did in the first and third waves, once it finishes its current "trend channel," the market will begin to fall. "At the current angle of ascent, I'm not calling a top [in the short term]," he said Monday on CNBC's "Trading Nation." "We could have a bit more of a rally, potentially reaching the 3,000 mark in the S&P 500." That would represent a 20 percent rise from Monday's closing price. Once the S&P does reach 3,000 the index could be set to come crashing down to 1,800, Gordon said. That would represent a 40 percent drop from those peaks.

The U.S. Yield Curve Is Flattening and Here's Why It Matters Yield curves are the flattest in a decade, and it’s no coincidence that about 10 years ago marked the start of an 18-month recession. The yield curve has proven a reliable indicator of impending economic slumps when it inverts, and short rates exceed longer-term yields. To get a sense of just how dramatic this trend has been, here’s a look at a handful of curve measures now versus the start of 2017. In trading Monday, they were all close to the flattest levels in a decade.     From two years to 10 years: 72 basis points, down from 125
    From two years to 30 years: 119 basis points, down from 187
    From five years to 10 years: 33 basis points, down from 52
    From five years to 30 years: 80 basis points, down from 114
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-13/the-u-s-yield-curve-is-flattening-and-here-s-why-it-matters
https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-bonds/treasuries-u-s-two-year-yields-touch-9-year-high-curve-flattening-resumes-idUSL1N1NJ0RR The Yield Curve as a Predictor of Economic Growth The slope of the yield curve—the difference between the yields on short- and long-term maturity bonds—has achieved some notoriety as a simple forecaster of economic growth. The rule of thumb is that an inverted yield curve (short rates above long rates) indicates a recession in about a year, and yield curve inversions have preceded each of the last seven recessions (as defined by the NBER). One of the recessions predicted by the yield curve was the most recent one. The yield curve inverted in August 2006, a bit more than a year before the current recession started in December 2007. There have been two notable false positives: an inversion in late 1966 and a very flat curve in late 1998.
https://www.clevelandfed.org/en/our-research/indicators-and-data/yield-curve-and-gdp-growth.aspx Q. What does the evidence say, in short? A. The difference between long-term and short-term interest rates ("the slope of the yield curve" or "the term spread") has borne a consistent negative relationship with subsequent real economic activity in the United States, with a lead time of about four to six quarters.

With 37 trading days left this year, a year that hasn't seen a drop larger than 1.5% on a daily basis, and investor's reactions have generally been muted to what was once market moving news, it seems unlikely that a 20% drop will happen in the next 37 days. Now most investors would argue that my comment supports the theory of an extreme drop, since the market has been so quiet. But I disagree.  Here is why: The S&P 500 drops 20% every 3.5 years, 15% drop once every 2 years, 10% drop once a year, and 5% drop 3 times per year. So far this year the S&P 500 hasn't dropped much more than 1.5% on a given day. In 2017 we have had on 3.0% decline and 3 other 2%+ declines. Last time we had a 5% drop was in August 2016. The last time we had a 15% drop was in November 2015, and the last time we saw a 20% drop was 2011.  So to compare to history: 
3 per year 5% drops - Actual is None. But we have had four 2% to 3% drops in 2017. NOT FORM FITTING
1 per year 10% drop - Actual is none.  The last drop of 10% of more was in Nov 2015; so 2 years ago. NOT FORM FITTING
1 per every 2 years 15% drop - Actual is 1 in the last two years. FORM FITTING
1 per every 3.5 years 20% drop - Actual was in 2011. So 6 years ago. NOT FORM FITTING Going back through the data, a 20% drop is highly unlikely. Although the data indicates they happen every 3.5 years, that is not a consistent 3.5 years. The drop during the Great Recession was 53%+. Then in 2011 we dropped 21%. Since 2011 we haven't dropped more than 20% during any time period.  To achieve a 20% decline, there must be underlying issues with the fundamentals of the market. As of now, GDP growth, unemployment, interest rates, and corporate profits are generally positive and improving. As such, I don't see a large deterioration in the market to warrant a 20% happening in the next 37 days.

While I certainly don't share the crowd's optimism about the stock market, investing is a relative game:  
Would investors rather own stocks priced to return 7.5% or Bonds Priced to yield 3.5%?    The spread between stocks and bonds is much wider than normal, suggesting one of two things:  
1)  the S&P is cheap relative to bonds which should help S&P valuations in the near-term or 
2) bonds as a whole are overpriced, which could result in a decline in both valuations.   Taking these into account, along with the relatively short time-line for a 20% decline to occur, I've modeled the odds of a 20% drop from the current valuations at roughly 7%.  If this were still a 1-yr prediction the odds would climb to more 27%.

The Fed has raised rates twice this year, and is widely expected to do so again in December. But even as the short-term interest rate targeted by the Fed has climbed, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury has fallen, a reversal of what usually happens and a development that Kaplan said he sees as “a little ominous.” “I view that as a comment on future economic growth,” Kaplan said at the Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research. “And what I don’t want to see us do is raise rates so fast that we get an inverted yield curve because history has shown an inverted yield curve has tended to be a precursor to a recession.” 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-kaplan/feds-kaplan-says-low-10-year-yield-an-ominous-sign-idUSKBN1CG005?il=0 This market indicator has predicted the past 7 recessions. Here's where it may be headed next     An inverted yield curve, which has correctly predicted the last seven recessions going back to the late 1960's, occurs when short-term interest rates yield more than longer-term rates.
    The last two times the yield curve inverted was in the years 2000 and 2006 before each of the last recessions.
    Here's why I predict the yield curve will invert again by the end of 2017.
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/05/inverted-yield-curve-predicting-coming-recession-commentary.html Inverted Yield Curve as Recession Predictor An inverted yield curve has predicted the last seven recessions dating back to the 1960's. The most recent was in 2006 when Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve increased the Fed funds rate 400 basis points and the 10-year yield rose less than 50 basis points. Economists at the time dismissed this, saying "this time it's different," and the economy is in better shape. "I don't get the sense that there is any panic because firms have learned a lot since 2000 about being prudent," an analyst at Celent said in 2005. Oh, how they were wrong. 
The Inverted Yield Curve Guide to Recession 
http://www.investopedia.com/news/inverted-yield-curve-guide-recession/ Q. What does the evidence say, in short? A. The difference between long-term and short-term interest rates ("the slope of the yield curve" or "the term spread") has borne a consistent negative relationship with subsequent real economic activity in the United States, with a lead time of about four to six quarters. The measures of the yield curve most frequently employed are based on differences between interest rates on Treasury securities of contrasting maturities, for instance, ten years minus three months. The measures of real activity for which predictive power has been found include GNP and GDP growth, growth in consumption, investment and industrial production, and economic recessions as dated by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER). The specific accuracy of these predictions depends on the particular measures employed, as well as on the estimation and prediction periods. However, the results are generally statistically significant and compare favorably with other variables employed as leading indicators. For instance, models that predict real GDP growth or recessions tend to explain 30 percent or more of the variation in the measure of real activity. See Estrella and Hardouvelis (1991). The yield curve has predicted essentially every U.S. recession since 1950 with only one "false" signal, which preceded the credit crunch and slowdown in production in 1967. There is also evidence that the predictive relationships exist in other countries, notably Germany, Canada, and the United Kingdom. See Estrella and Mishkin (1997) and Bernard and Gerlach (1998).

Couple of items I'm thinking about/watching at the moment that could cause me to tweak baseline assumption -- Fed policy and economic data:  Most recent Fed statement is interesting -- sounds like there might be no more rate hikes this year but balance sheet reduction will start "soon." I believe rate hikes pose a greater risk to economic activity than balance sheet tapering, the mechanics of the former are clearer, more direct. However, to the extent that (1) tapering negatively impacts investor sentiment (balance sheet expansion seems to have supported it), market psychology could deteriorate, or (2) tapering (fundamentally and/or psychologically driven) causes credit spreads to widen, risk of 20% decline could increase marginally.  Coincident economic indicators havce continued to deteriorate (see Phil Fed's latest state-level indexes: https://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/regional-economy/indexes/coincident). In 2008, the highest recorded closing value of the index was $1425.35 on May 16th. By October 3rd, it had fallen by a little over 20%. We are talking a slow drip, to a sudden drop, of approximately 5 months' time. Going off of this historical reference as a recent data point, 6 months remain in 2017, thus there is a still a window of opportunity for a similar fall to occur. Ok, so probability is greater than 0%. But how much greater than 0%? Not too much, given the current bull market's penchant for the often-quoted from Warren Buffett "...be greedy when others are fearful" that seems to be on everyone's lips these days. The recent quick sell-off and subsequent re-buying of FAANG at a "discount" when Goldman Sachs released their report comparing FAANG to the previous tech bubble of 2000/2001 is an interesting example of how the quote above seems to be thrown around by a lot of newbie AND seasoned investors lately. Because of this, it seems to me that the market is likely to weather any small corrections or downturns that may result over the course of the year due to this renewed sense of confidence that even first-time investors are showing when these opportunities to buy stocks at a "discount" arise. So, if a slow drip is unlikely, that only leaves possibility of a sudden drop. The overconnectedness of stop-losses resulting from an initial sell-off by major players will quickly wipe a significant portion of the market's value due to tenuous emotional confidence within the market at the moment. Many investors claim to be emotionally strong to hold on and weather a drop, and then buy back the "discounted" stocks, but I think the recent FAANG scenario brought out a lot of anxiety investors are hiding with regards to wanting to secure the gains they've made over these last 8-9 years. If anyone reading this frequents online stock forums/messaging boards, they will know what I am referring to. Right after that report was published and people saw the markets open at a significant loss for the first time in a while, plenty of individuals online started to question their investments very quickly. I view it as a warning sign for things to come, when a sudden drop exceeds the emotional resistance of most investors. Might be sooner than we think depending on various underlying macroeconomic trends, such as potentially diminishing consumption due to rising student debt and subprime auto lending.

Optimally I would check how often these falls have happened and use that as a base rate. But I do not have the exact data. On Wikipedia I found data of annual price changes in the index going back to 1970. There were three falls of 20% (2008, 2000 and 1974). This ignores the maximum spike and valleys within the years. To compensate I instead count years with drops of 17% or more, which leads to adding 1973. So our base rate is 4/46 = 9% We have a joker-factor in flash crashes. Since 2010 Wiki says we have had 4 significant ones, though from my sloppy reading none of them effected S&P in this way, but almost. A possible flash-crash factor to add to the base rate is 7%. We have no good data about how frequent these things are. We have a combined base rate of 16%. Which we reduce by 25% because that is how much has gone of the year. We land at 12% Now the particulars of our year. We have lots that points towards fragility and risk for general oddity happening. High loans, uniquely low interest-rates, a higher than average P-E-ratio: 23. From 1900 to 1990 a P-E this high was always followed by a crash, or was its effect. 15 or 18 or something is the historical average. On its own I would want this to adjust the base rate up by 30%. I could analyze the history to count how often in high-p-e-years we have these falls, but am to lazy. Then the risk for crisis from high debts. Make up a 30% modifier. Then we can add something for political instability. What we have seen come out of Trump has been pro-business. Risk for war? Small wars are not bad for business. Markets - yes, but not the big companies that make up the S&P. I put this to a 30%-modifier. 12% *1,3*1,3*1,3=26" The things I feel are fishy about my prediction:
I sort of want the risk to be high. And may have fudged up the factors. I plainly made them up. If I keep inventing new factors to adjust by I can reach any probability I want to. One should always decide which factors to include and how to weigh them in advance. To stop the risk of nudging into subjectivity.

The index is expensive by historical standards. These things cannot be timed. It might seem that current valuation levels alone would justify a higher likelihood than normal. But what constitutes 'normal'? The ultimate historical dataset on this courtesy of Bob Shiller (http://www.econ.yale.edu/~shiller/data/ie_data.xls), which contains monthly price and total returns back to 1871, including earnings data for the S&P 500 index, and its predecessor. Now assuming eight months left of the year (a slight oversimplification) we see that the SPX/GSPC returns a price return of minus 20% inside eight months in 4.5% of all calendar months. But conditioning on current valuation levels with CAPE at the time of writing @ 29.19, we see that in only six of 79 months (7.6% of cases) have markets been more expensive than currently in terms of Graham-Dodd/Shiller PE, with subsequent eight-month price return equal to or more negative than minus 20%. This is not what I had expected and there is a lesson there in terms of judging the question based on historical evidence rather than gut feel! Now there are obviously various caveats that suggest that all things are NOT equal. Specifically, capital markets are more liquid, transparent etc, etc, while the composition of assets has also seen a structural change towards non-tangible assets. This means that traditionally reported earnings may mean less that previously (Amazon rarely reports a profit, yet it is not a top ten company by market cap globally). This is counter-balanced by global imbalances relating to a potential China blow-up + Eurozone crisis. But on balance, I will stick with the historical likelihood.

I have gone to 100 because of other factors like the Fear and Greed Index, P/E ratios, Schiller, debt, etc etc. Predicting Stock Market Returns—Lose the Normal and Switch to Laplace A well-known problem in financial risk assessment is the failure of the normal distribution (also known as the Gaussian distribution) to correctly predict big up or down days on the stock market.  The Issue  My interest in this area stems from the frequent use of sigma notation by commenters when the market experiences big swings.  For example, there was a multi-day10 sigma increase in the value of the VIX index associated with the August 2015 correction and an 8 sigma single day downswing a couple of weeks later. Once you get past +-4 sigma moves it’s hard to visualize how vast the differences are between the S&P 500 actual returns and the predictions of the normal distribution. The vertical dotted black line on the right side of the chart illustrates the problem.  In the last 67 years, the S&P has had two days with returns between +5.5% and +5.6%.  The normal distribution estimates the probability of one event of that magnitude as 0.0001 in 67 years (where the dotted black line touches the red line) —in other words, we should expect a move near +5.5% once in 67,000 years on average—and in reality, we’ve had two of them in 67 years! From a risk analysis standpoint, this is analogous to building your house above the 67,000-year flood line and being flooded out twice in the last 67 years. This adjusted Laplace distribution closely matches the S&P 500 historical data in predicting that every year there’s around a 75% chance of having a 5 sigma or higher event—a far cry from the normal distribution’s prediction of once per 6900 years.
https://sixfigureinvesting.com/2016/03/modeling-stock-market-returns-with-laplace-distribution-instead-of-normal/

Since 1951 there have been 1159 days out of 16,663 days when the S&P 500 has traded 20% below the preceding ~365 days (I used 251 trading days to approximate a year).  This is a 6.96% chance on any day out of the days sampled that the market would close 20% below the preceding  ~365 day high.  Three things to note:  (1) what is now the S&P 500 did not start tracking 500 stocks until 1957 and the stocks tracked have changed over time; (2) periods when the S&P 500 closes 20% below the 365 day max roughly correlate to accepted recessions, but this measure is often late to call the recession or shows a 20% drop when there was no accepted recession; and (3)  my estimate is only relevant for the last day of 2017 given the wording of the problem and since our 2017 high (so far) was March 1st, my 6.96% estimate is too high as there are not 251 trading days left in the year. Of course, these 1159 days are clustered, so the question becomes are we close to the start of a new cluster. Since some of these pullbacks have been associated with recessions, it may be appropriate to ask if we have any factors that would predict a recession. (I don’t have an answer to this, but would love to see some good evidence for or against a possible recession). As a side note, here’s a similar analysis of the S&P 500:  from 1983 to 2012 “18% of quarters have a price at least 20% below the 4 quarter trailing high (average 0.73 times per year)”
 (http://qvmgroup.com/invest/2013/03/19/how-often-does-sp-500-have-10-and-20-negative-price-moves/).  Another consideration is that the market is simply over valued and might see a correction (some of those clusters were not associated with recessions), but by how much? We have seen a pretty clear “Trump Narrative” after the election, but there is some argument to be made that this “Trump narrative” of growth and lower taxes broke down last week and that we now await a new narrative (https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-comes-after-the-trump-trade-for-markets-1490285715). This Trump trade has only yielded about 12% and really a little bit less because there was a little downturn right before the election.  Is the market over valued? Probably. Several people have already linked to some nice breakdowns of this topic, but it is important to remember that accounting standard have changed so one must be careful in interpreting historical data (even my own) (http://www.arcap.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/CapeShiller.pdf). The question becomes:  Will the S&P 500 go down12% (the Trump Trade), plus the extra 8% needed to reach 20% before the end of 2017? For now I’ll say about 5%. We will undoubtedly have another correction; I just don’t think it will happen in 2017 without a nearly black swan level event.

This measure (decline to trough from same-calendar-year high) seems somewhat contrived from an investment standpoint; an investor would typically care about peak to trough drawdown without constraining that measure to specific calendar years. As it is, you have to also make a judgment about where/when a peak might occur, rather than anchoring to the most recent peak. Be that as it may...  Running historical data (daily closing price levels from Jan 1950 through Dec 2016), I get 10 years where S&P 500 fell 20% or more from its intra-calendar-year high: 1957, 1962, 1966, 1970, 1973, 1974, 1987, 2001, 2002 and 2008 (near misses in 1990 and 2011 of -19.9% and -19.4%, respectively). Frequency is 15%, 20% if we include the two near misses.  For what it's worth, these episodes were far more frequent from 1960s to mid-1970s, rare in the 1980s and 90s, and more common again in the 2000s. If you include the near misses, the only period where such intrayear declines were truly rare was the mid-1980s.  Counting only declines of 20% or more, the average occurence was 1.67 out of every rolling 10-year period. We're currently at 1 in the past 10 years (2008). Not sure this provides much information. Including 1990 and 2011, this figure becomes 2.12 and we're currently at 2 (2008, 2011). According to this measure, we're historically in line (slightly below) until the end of 2017. Not a lot of information in that, but could pull the probability for this year *very slightly* lower.  Re economic data, most senitment indicators are surprising to the upside, and there appears to be a synchronized global recovery taking hold. Labor markets have shown improvement in some important areas, although Fed's labor market conditions index has been soft, and labor tends to be a late-cycle indicator. Neutral on the economic outlook and its potential impact, although slightly biased to the upside. It might be helpful to compare various economic indicators to historic S&P500 price data.  I still view Fed hikes, FBI's ongoing investigation into Russian influence, and House GOP's fervent belief that federal government spending is revenue constrained as meaningful risk factors to US equities. Based on its March statement, I think the Fed is unlikely to derail equity markets this calendar year. On the second one, even in a most chaotic outcome (e.g., resignations and/or impeachments within the executive branch), it seems entirely out of the question that 2016 election results would be overturned. Thus, GOP should maintain control of executive and both houses of Congress. (Of course, such an outcome could delay tax and regulatory changes that markets seem to be discounitng.) The third risk is the greater of the three, imo. In the near term, it is likely to mean spending increases and/or tax cuts with lower fiscal multipliers than spending that's being decreased and/or tax rates that are likely to increase. This remains to be seen, of course. Longer term (and probably less significant to the timeframe of this challenge question), a concerted pursuit of balanced federal budgets would (eventually) have negative consequences for risky assets like equities.  Also fair to say that US large-cap equities are fairly valued if not somewhat overvalued. It would help to have valuation data to compare to S&P500 price data. Without it, I'm not prepared to take too strong of a stand on the valuation angle. Robert Shiller’s favorite valuation method for the S&P 500, the cyclically adjusted price-to-earnings ratio, reached 30. The two times the CAPE ratio reached these levels, doom followed in the stock market. In 1929, it only stayed above 30 for about two months until Black Tuesday sparked a crash that sent stocks tumbling more than 80 percent from their peak. It happened again in mid-1997, but stocks and valuations continued to rise. The ratio eventually rose above 44 in late-1999 and stocks ran up almost 85 percent before eventually losing half their value by 2002 after the technology bubble burst.

Since 1962, there have been 16 drawdowns of 20% or more.  Five of these occurred in the same year as another drawdown, so there were 11 unique years.  Over this 55-year period then, the drawdown rate is running at 20%.  These years were characterized by overinflated stock values and “unusual circumstances”, e.g., oil price shocks, extremely high interest rates, the 1987 flash crash, the Internet bubble and the collapse of the housing market.  By some measures (Shiller CAPE PE10) the current stock market is significantly over-valued (by almost 50%).   However, using the data at http://www.econ.yale.edu/~shiller/data.htm and fitting a curve to the total real value over time suggests that the overvaluation is a less ominous 10%, which is historically not unusual.  Over the decades, the dividend rate has declined while total real value has faithfully followed an exponential growth rate, which is only explained by higher price-to-earnings ratios.  There is certainly potential for an "unusual circumstance" to develop during the year, but baring such an occurrence, the current direction of the economy is generally positive, and a 20% drawdown rate appears high.   The current value of the S&P 500 is 2,382, and at this level a probability of 15% seems more reasonable.  This probability would be re-evaluated if the market goes up significantly from here or if an “unusual circumstance” occurs.

Revising upward from 11% to account for intra-year declines.  In 6 of the last 36 years, there have been intra-year declines of 20% or greater.  That's a 16.7% probability based on recent history.  Notably, there were two years with 20% intra-year declines that ended up with positive returns:  1987 and 2009.  Therefore, looking only at calendar-year returns masks significant volatility.  The qualifying "bear" (20%+) declines are 1.5x what one would think based solely on calendar-year returns.  Moreover, there were two years with near-miss -19% intra-year declines (1998 and 2011) that ended up with positive returns for the calendar year (+29% and +2% respectively), which means the historical probability could easily have been 22% instead of 16.7%.  But I'll stick with 16.7% as a baseline, because the question is 20% declines, not 19%.   I multiply this 16.7% historical probability by 83% to account for the fact that there are now only 10 months left in the question, which gives me a 13.8% "outside view".  I lower this slightly to account for strong U.S. economic prospects:  sold job creation, corporate profit cycle acceleration, strong consumer and business confidence, with fiscal stimulus (tax cuts and infrastructure spending) layered on top.

I think it is impossible to try to "forecast" a market crash based on logical reasoning.
The CBOE has daily prices on its website going back 30 years (1986). During that time there have been five years in which the S&P500 has fallen more than 20% intra year: 1987, 2001, 2002, 2008, 2009
Arguably 2002 and 2009 should be discounted as they are existing bear markets. However, there were also 2 years with very near misses 1991 (-19.9%) and 1998 (-19.2%), so perhaps 5 in 30 is a reasonable starting point.
Looking further back I could only find monthly price data which is less accurate. There was definitely a 20%+ drop in 1974, suggesting 6 20%+ falls in the last 50 years. The fact that such falls are so irregular makes estimating the likelihood difficult.
Does the fact that the S&P is at an all time high and arguably overvalued increase the likelihood? Possibly. However, I don't think there is anything to suggest markets will be particularly volatile in 2017 relative to previous years. The spate of recent "flash crashes" in other markets and widespread automated trading suggests the chances of a crash similar to 1987 are higher. Overall, I think 1/7 for the full year is reasonable - around 12% adjusted for the fact we are nearly 2 months into the year.

It looks as if the S&P has entered a new secular bull market - starting around 2013.  In past bull markets the S & P fell 20% or more on major bubble blow outs. There were 3 such incidents in the last bull market from 1982 to 2000 that resulted in the S&P loosing 20% or more in the same year.  The 1987 crash is the outlier.  It happened 5 years into the bull market and market had rallied 176% since the beginning of the bull market.  We are 3 years into the new bull market and the S & P has rallied 49%. Still some way off from being hot.  During bear markets there are many more incidents of the S&P loosing 20% or more in a year. In the last bear market there were about 6.  So in the last bull market a 20% blow off happened every 6 years while in the bear market every 4 years however they tend to cluster more.

Looking at the presidential cycle in a bull market, if there is a 20% or more blow off there is a 66% probability it will happen in year 3. 3; a 33% probability of a correction in year 2.  Over both bull and bear markets if there is a blow off, there is a 50% probability of it happening in year 3 and a 30% probability of it happening in year 2.   As the markets move higher we see the probability increasing over the next two years.    I believe that there will not be a sell off of 20% or more in 2017. However there is always a black swan event risk, hence I have given a 5% probability for such an event in 2017.   I feel the probability of any of the know risks / bubbles cracking this year is low. I will update my answer as we get additional feed back during the year.

Based on monthly S&P 500 prices from the past 50 years, I count only 4 years in which there was a >20% drop in prices within 1 year: 1987: -26.8% (hi 329, lo 241) - Black Monday (illiquidity, computerized arbitrage)
2001: -21.8% (hi 1335, lo 1044) - 9/11 + Dot com collapse
2002: -25.9% (hi 1153, lo 854) - Dot com collapse
2008: -37.5% (hi 1403, lo 877) - Great Recession (weak regulations, real estate speculation, over-leverage) This gives us a baseline incidence of 8%. Stock market crashes tend to be exacerbated by panic, triggered by combination of: weak regulations, over-speculation, illiquidity, or a major geopolitical event. Current US financial regulations are moderate, despite Trump administrations efforts to weaken Dodd-Frank. There is little at present in the press about being in a potential bubble. Similarly, market liquidity has improved due to Obama administration's emphasis on stress-testing for major banks. This leaves us with only one major risk factor - a major geopolitical event. There are several potential hotspots in the world right now - Russian aggression in Europe, potential global turmoil triggered by collapse of foreign markets (e.g. slowing China economy, Venezuela default), deterioration of the Middle East (Saudi Arabia vs. Iran + Russian influence), and another 9/11-like terrorist attack. Using 8% as my base, I am simply increasing my prediction by 10% based on foreign factors. This is a black swan question if ever there was one. An event that would cause markets to pursue a 20 % revaluation in equities is by its nature an unforeseen game changer, something that was not priced in previously at all. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/447634 gives a good overview for the overall trend. On top of that, I would list possible downsize risks and evaluate their probability. 1) Bankruptcy of a systemically important institution (Deutsche Bank, a major UK bank struggling with Brexit, a major Italian bank struggling with NPLs). Good study on systemic importance here https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2012/wp12282.pdf. Extremely unlikely, although a bailout could still rock markets. 2) Deterioration of the trading relationship between the US and China. Possible, but unlikely in a sudden way that would trigger market stress. 3) Political risks in Europe. Unlikely and in addition limited impact on US markets (Brexit caused a 6% fall in the S&P) Even a Le Pen presidency and/or Cinque Sterre coming to power in Italy, would probably not cause this. 4) Sudden revaluation of a key asset class (such as CMBSs). Unlikely 5) A flash crash or other extreme price swing due to automated trading. Unlikely and by definition the recovery is immediate and not reflected in the end-of-day closing level. IF one of these risks triggered, the effects would be exacerbated by current regulation affecting market functioning. The excessive metrics of the capital ratio, leverage ratio, LCR and NSFR, though conceived as safe guards against future crises, have rendered banks incapable of performing many of their basic intermediation tasks, including taking on board risk that other parties (institutional investors) cannot take on. This is mainly affecting the fixed income markets, but in case a stress scenario is triggered, for whatever reason, it will inevitably spill over into equity markets as well. With liquidity drying up due to banks inability to participate in the markets, other entities will have to engage in fire sales to make a flight to safety out of equities, into treasuries or gold for instance, which will cause stock prices to plunge. The Trump administration is planning amendments to Dodd-Frank, but the details are unknown at this stage. If done in a sensible way that restores banks as fully functioning intermediaries and transferors of risk, the above risk is mitigated. The FED has also proved in the past that it is very much proactive in handling market stress situations and would likely quickly step in to calm markets. All in all, I feel the probability of a 20 % fall in the S&P 500 is low, although there are mechanisms (automated trading, current regulatory environment) in place that can magnify a medium sized market movement into a severe one. The overall outlook for US equities however remains positive.

Initial forecast. Surprised there are so few comments regarding world wide macroeconomics. Seems (even absent the interesting US political situation) that there is more than a bit of uncertainty regarding all markets. As we've seen, one blip may or may not be able to be contained and several of the equities and real estate markets have at least a bit of froth (technical jargon ;-).

Since 1929 there is a 26% probability of a negative one-year return of any magnitude:  http://awealthofcommonsense.com/2015/11/playing-the-probabilities/  Although it is possible to have a 20% decline from a peak and still end the year positive, that is very unlikely.    Given the average standard deviation of stock price returns, I estimate the probability of a 20% downside move to be roughly 15%.  Since World War II, there have been 15 bear markets in the S&P 500.  That's about 21% of the years.  Taken together, this evidence indicates an "outside view" of a 15% to 26% likelihood of a 20% decline; call it 20%.   There are several reasons why I think 2017 has a lower than average risk of a bear market. First, the economy is reasonably strong.  Second, there is a good probability of a fiscal stimulus in the form of infrastructure spending.  Third, profit growth is accelerating.  I think this adds up to less than half the usual odds of a bear market, or a roughly 1 in 10 chance.   The main risk to my forecast is a Fed that raises rates too quickly.  I don't think that is a big risk, given that more members are currently dovish (6) than are hawkish (5) looking at the Fed's "dot" plot.
